Prompt:
Example 1:
Daniel was but eight years old, a boy of striking appearance, with black hair and eyes, and a swarthy complexion. He was of slender frame, and his large dark eyes, deep set beneath an overhanging brow, gave a singular appearance to the thin face of the delicate looking boy. He was a farmer's son, and lived in a plain, old-fashioned house, shaded by fine elms, and separated from the broad, quiet street by a fence. It was situated in a valley, at the bend of the Merrimac, on both sides of which rose high hills, which the boy climbed many a time for the more extended view they commanded. From a high sheep-pasture on his father's farm, through a wide opening in the hills, he could see on a clear day Brentney Mountain in Vermont, and in a different direction the snowy top of Mount Washington, far away to the northeast.

Example 2:
There is no specific scientific calculator prescribed for this subject. Any scientific, nonprogrammable calculator is suitable for your studies. Different scientific calculators have different functions and it is up to you to know your calculator. Most scientific calculators have algebraic logic; the operation in an expression can be entered in the calculator in the order in which the expression is read (left to right). The calculator automatically follows the conventional order of operations. 
You can setup your calculator to work either in natural display or linear display. Natural display causes fractions, irrational numbers, expressions, and certain functions to be displayed as you see them on paper. Linear display causes fractions and other expressions to be displayed in a line. 
When we come across an expression such as 7 + 3 ÷ 10 × 1, it makes a difference how we choose which operations to perform first.
Scientific calculators have been programmed to follow preset mathematical rules. If we press the buttons in a certain order, the calculator does the operations according to the rules that it has been programmed with.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (High School), limited to 50 words. 

Prehistory is the period of time before written records. During this era, humans evolved from early forms, developing language, tools, and complex societies. Archaeologists study prehistoric cultures through artifacts, fossils, and other remnants. It is a mysterious and fascinating time, providing clues to human origins and early civilizations.​ ​  ​ ​ ​​​
 
Answer: 

Prehistory, the period before written records, is a mysterious and fascinating time. During this era, humans evolved from early forms, developing language, tools, and complex societies. Archaeologists study prehistoric cultures through artifacts, fossils, and remnants, uncovering clues to human origins and early civilizations.  ​​​ ​​​ ​​​

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (High School), limited to 50 words. 

Prehistory refers to the period before written records, spanning millions of years. This era saw the emergence of early humans, development of tools, and the rise of complex societies. It is an age of discovery, with artifacts and fossils revealing the lives of ancient peoples.  It's a vast, uncharted territory.  The dawn of human history began in Africa, where early humans evolved.  The history of prehistory remains a subject of ongoing research and debate.  Our understanding of this era is constantly evolving.  Its mysteries are slowly being uncovered.  Fossils and artifacts are being found in increasing numbers.  New discoveries are shedding light on the lives of early humans.  The more we learn, the more we realize how little we know.  The study of prehistory is a fascinating journey.  It takes us back to the beginning of human history.  It reveals the early struggles and triumphs of our ancestors.  It shows us the gradual development of human societies.

From a high sheep-pasture on his father's farm, through a wide opening in the hills, he could see on a clear day Brentney Mountain in Vermont, and in a different direction the snowy top of Mount Washington, far away to the northeast.

There is no specific scientific calculator prescribed for this subject. Any scientific, nonprogrammable calculator is suitable for your studies. Different scientific calculators have different functions and it is up to you to know your calculator. Most scientific calculators have algebraic logic; the operation in an expression can be entered in the calculator in the order in which the expression is read (left to right). The calculator automatically follows the conventional order of operations. 
You can setup your calculator to work either in natural display or linear display. Natural display causes fractions, irrational numbers, expressions, and certain functions to be displayed as you see them on paper. Linear display causes fractions and other expressions to be displayed in a line. 
When we come across an expression such as 7 + 3 ÷ 10 × 1, it makes a difference how we choose which operations to perform first.
Scientific calculators have been programmed to follow preset mathematical rules. If we press the buttons in a certain order, the calculator does the operations according to the rules that it has been programmed with.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (High School), limited to 50 words. 
Prehistory, a vast period, spans over 2.5 million years. The era before recorded history, it encompasses the development of early humans and the evolution of life on Earth. The landscape, the climate, and the people, all underwent significant changes during this time. It was a period of discovery.  The transition to agriculture, the development of tools, and the emergence of complex societies, all laid the foundation for the modern world.  The study of prehistory, through archaeology and anthropology, helps us understand our past and the origins of human civilization.​  The discovery of ancient artifacts, such as fossils, and the deciphering of written symbols, provide valuable insights into the lives of our ancestors.  Through these findings, we can glimpse the lives of the people who lived before us.​

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (High School), limited to 50 words. 
Prehistory spans the time before written records. Archaeologists study artifacts, like tools, pottery, and architecture, to understand past societies. By analyzing these relics, they can piece together a picture of how early humans lived and interacted. This glimpse into the past reveals the origins of modern cultures.
